results_summary: Fe:EDDS was more effective in pharmaceutical removal (80%) compared to Fe:IDS (58%), while Fe:IDS showed superior pathogen inactivation (4.3 log reduction for E. coli vs. 1.9 log for Fe:EDDS). Combining SPF with sunlight/H2O2 had mixed effects on disinfection efficacy.
population_specificity: Urban wastewater samples containing pharmaceuticals and pathogens.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the photocatalytic activity of Fe3O4@D-wood under artificial sunlight for water treatment and radical photopolymerization.
results_summary: Fe3O4@D-wood demonstrated improved photochemical oxidation of organic pollutants in the presence of H2O2 and efficiently generated reactive radicals for photopolymerization, particularly with UDMA and TPGDA mixtures using cumene hydroperoxide (CHP).
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the degradation of ketamine under sunlight irradiation in the presence of chlorine and elucidate the reactive species involved.
results_summary: Sunlight/chlorine effectively degraded ketamine, with •OH dominating the initial stage and O3 becoming the major reactant after chlorine depletion. O3 contributed significantly to ketamine removal, and sunlight enhanced degradation rates.
population_specificity: Environmental (water treatment systems)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether simulated sunlight enhances the toxicity of nano titanium dioxide (nTiO2) to rotifers compared to LED light.
results_summary: The study found that simulated sunlight significantly increased the toxicity of nTiO2 to rotifers, evidenced by lower survival rates, reduced reproductive parameters, and higher oxidative stress markers compared to LED light. Vitamin C mitigated some adverse effects, suggesting oxidative damage as a key mechanism.
population_specificity: Brachionus calyciflorus (rotifers)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sunlight could effectively drive the degradation of tetracycline (TC) using a Ag3PO4/MIL-101(Fe) composite system through photocatalysis and photo-Fenton catalysis.
results_summary: The study found that sunlight-driven photocatalysis and photo-Fenton catalysis using the composite system achieved optimal TC degradation, with a maximum degradation rate of 2.5730 min−1. The composite also reduced photocorrosion of Ag3PO4 and produced less toxic intermediates compared to Ag3PO4 alone.
population_specificity: Not specified (environmental/chemical study)
effective_dosage: Not specified (mass ratio of MIL-101(Fe) to Ag3PO4 was 5:1 for optimal degradation)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the correlation between sunlight exposure patterns and immunotherapy response in metastatic melanoma and establish predictive nomograms for survival rates.
results_summary: The study found that sunlight exposure patterns correlated with immunotherapy efficacy, with head and neck melanoma showing the greatest survival improvement. Nomograms accurately predicted 3- and 5-year overall survival rates.
population_specificity: Metastatic melanoma patients from the SEER database (2005-2016), divided by primary site sunlight exposure patterns (head/neck, trunk/arms/legs, acral sites).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of iron molybdate nanoparticles (FeMoO4) in photo-assisted activation of persulfate systems for degrading organic pollutants in wastewater.
results_summary: The study found that I-FeMoO4 effectively degraded various organic dyes and antibiotics within 5-60 minutes under light-assisted conditions, demonstrating good recoverable stability without secondary pollution. The degradation mechanism was explored through radical trapping and EPR tests.
population_specificity: Not applicable (wastewater treatment study).
effective_dosage: 0.6 g L-1 of persulfate and 0.4 g L-1 of I-FeMoO4.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the practices and factors associated with neonatal sunlight exposure among mothers in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.
results_summary: The study found that 27.1% of mothers practiced good neonatal sunlight exposure, with factors like advanced neonatal age, larger family size, and complete antenatal care associated with better practices, while poor knowledge and fear of sunlight exposure were linked to poor practices.
population_specificity: Mothers attending public hospitals in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.
effective_dosage: 30 to 60 minutes of morning sunlight (8:00 to 10:00).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a TiO2/3D-GF/Ni hybrid photocatalyst in degrading methyl orange dye under simulated sunlight.
results_summary: The hybrid nanomaterial achieved over 90% decolorization of methyl orange within 30 minutes under simulated sunlight and maintained 99.5% efficiency after three cycles, demonstrating high photocatalytic performance.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study using a chemical dye).
effective_dosage: Not specified (photocatalyst performance measured under irradiance conditions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a natural sunlight-active photocatalyst (ZnO-coated face-mask fabric) for photocatalytic water treatment to degrade pollutants.
results_summary: The study found that ZnO-coated face-mask fabric achieved 91% degradation efficiency under natural sunlight in 100 minutes, comparable to 99% efficiency under UV light. Unique morphologies and solvent properties influenced the degradation efficiency.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study, no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a BiOIO3/AgIO3 hybrid photocatalyst in degrading persistent organic pollutants (POPs) under natural sunlight.
results_summary: The Bi@Ag-5 composite photocatalyst demonstrated high efficiency in degrading various pollutants under natural sunlight, with degradation rates significantly surpassing those of pristine AgIO3 and BiOIO3, as well as commercial TiO2 (P25). The photocatalyst achieved notable reductions in COD, TOC, and chromaticity values in a scaled-up experiment.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on pollutant degradation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize silver nanoparticles (Ag NPs) using Linum usitatissimum extract and evaluate their photocatalytic, antibacterial, anticancer, antioxidant, and electrocatalytic activities.
results_summary: The study found that Ag NPs exhibited high antibacterial activity against multiple bacterial strains, strong anticancer effects against specific cancer cell lines, significant antioxidant activity, and effective photocatalytic degradation of methylene blue. They also demonstrated electrocatalytic potential for hydrogen peroxide detection.
population_specificity: In vitro testing on bacterial strains (S. aureus, E. coli, B. subtilis, MRSA) and cancer cell lines (HT-29, MDA-MB-231, L929, MIA PaCa-2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the photocatalytic activity and environmental safety of Sn/Mn-ZnFe2O4-CdFe2O4-Ag3PO4 Quantum dots (M/SZFO-CFO-AP QDs) for degrading doxycycline in water under visible light.
results_summary: The study found that M/SZFO-CFO-AP QDs achieved 98.8% degradation efficiency of doxycycline and 98.9% total organic carbon removal, indicating complete mineralization. The material showed low toxicity in Allium Cepa tests and enhanced growth in treated bean plants.
population_specificity: Environmental application (water treatment) and plant model (Allium Cepa and bean plants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if simulated sunlight-induced NOM activation of peroxymonosulfate (PMS) could effectively reduce ultrafiltration membrane fouling caused by natural organic matter in river water.
results_summary: The study found that at 200 mW/cm² light intensity and 0.5 mM PMS, the pretreatment removed 57.5% of UV254 and 18.5% of DOC, degraded humic-like fluorescent components by 84%-94%, and increased membrane flux by 94%. The method also reduced reversible and irreversible fouling resistances by 62.4% and 51.9%, respectively.
population_specificity: Songhua River water (environmental sample, not human subjects)
effective_dosage: 200 mW/cm² light intensity and 0.5 mM PMS

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how external pH influences endogenous solar inactivation processes in sunlight-dependent wastewater treatment systems, specifically for E. coli and enterococci.
results_summary: Elevated solar inactivation rates were observed at pH 4 for all bacterial populations and at pH 10 for E. coli. UVB light played a significant role in inactivation, though its contribution diminished for Enterococcus spp. under acidic conditions, suggesting enhanced indirect inactivation pathways.
population_specificity: Laboratory-cultured and wastewater-sourced E. coli and enterococci.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of sunlight exposure versus oral vitamin D3 supplementation in achieving vitamin D sufficiency in breastfed infants by 6 months of age.
results_summary: Sunlight exposure (40% body surface area for ≥30 minutes/week) was less effective than oral vitamin D3 supplementation (400 IU/day) in achieving vitamin D sufficiency, with no significant improvement in the sunlight group and two infants developing rickets. Compliance was also lower in the sunlight group (59.7%) compared to the vitamin D group (72.9%).
population_specificity: Breastfed infants aged 6-8 weeks at enrollment in Northern India.
effective_dosage: 40% body surface area sunlight exposure for a minimum of 30 minutes per week.
study_duration: Intervention lasted until infants reached 6 months of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of reactive chlorine species (RCSs) in enhancing the degradation of benzotriazole (BT) and 5-methyl-1H-benzotriazole (5-MeBT) during the sunlight/free chlorine process.
results_summary: Sunlight/free chlorine significantly enhanced the degradation of BT and 5-MeBT compared to sunlight or chlorination alone, with higher degradation rates under alkaline conditions due to the dominant role of RCSs like ClO•. The process resulted in hydroxylation and chlorine substitution of BT, with no detected Microtox® toxicity in treated solutions.
population_specificity: Aquatic environments (not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (chlorine dosage varied but exact amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sunlight reflected from mobile device screens could cause solar maculopathy without direct sun gaze.
results_summary: The study found that sunlight reflected from mobile device screens in high-radiation environments (ski center, beach) caused solar maculopathy in two patients, with one showing complete resolution after two years and the other retaining retinal defects.
population_specificity: Two Caucasian individuals (a 30-year-old man and a 20-year-old woman).
effective_dosage: Not specified (exposure durations: 4 hours and 3 hours, respectively).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the photocatalytic properties of layered molybdenum (meta)phosphate [MoO2(PO3)2] for wastewater treatment, specifically for reducing toxic Cr6+ to Cr3+ and degrading organic dyes like methylene blue.
results_summary: The study found that MoO2(PO3)2 completed photoreduction of Cr6+ to Cr3+ in 6 minutes and achieved 78% degradation efficiency for methylene blue in 36 minutes, with reactive species like O2 •-, •OH, and h+ playing key roles.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on wastewater treatment).
study_duration: 6 minutes for Cr6+ reduction, 36 minutes for methylene blue degradation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of zinc oxide nanohybrids in purifying water from colored pollutants using sunlight.
results_summary: The study found that zinc oxide nanohybrids reduced the band gap energy, making them effective in sunlight, and achieved complete removal of colored pollutants (naphthol green B) within ten minutes. The approach showed promise for addressing water purification using renewable energy.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how natural sunlight irradiation affects the biotoxicity of dissolved organic matter in wastewater treatment plant effluents and compare it to standard natural organic matter.
results_summary: Sunlight irradiation reduced the genotoxicity of effluent organic matter (EfOM) by degrading high-unsaturation components, while luminescent bacteria toxicity varied based on molecular size and characteristics. Smaller molecules (<1 kDa) with higher humification and fluorescence showed increased toxicity under sunlight.
population_specificity: Effluent organic matter (EfOM) from domestic wastewater treatment plants and standard natural organic matter (SRNOM) from the Suwannee River.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel eco-friendly photocatalyst (WO3NCs@LoP) for photodegradation of organic pollutants in wastewater under visible-light illumination.
results_summary: The study found that WO3NCs@LoP achieved a 99% removal rate of methylene blue within 20 minutes under visible light, outperforming pure LoP and WO3NCs. The photocatalyst also demonstrated high stability and reusability, retaining 85% activity after 9 cycles.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study using synthetic wastewater).
study_duration: Not specified (time points measured up to 20 minutes for degradation and 9 cycles for stability).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-term and long-term status of monocular eye closure in sunlight after surgical treatment of intermittent exotropia.
results_summary: Monocular eye closure disappeared in 43% of patients short-term and 50% long-term post-surgery. Most patients maintained their short-term status long-term, with few changes.
population_specificity: Patients aged 4 years and older who underwent surgery for intermittent exotropia with monocular eye closure in sunlight.
study_duration: Short-term follow-up (≤6 months) and long-term follow-up (mean 7.12 ± 2.89 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficiency of CoFe2O4/SiO2/flower-like MnO2 nanoparticles as a catalyst for Cr(VI) removal via adsorption-photocatalytic processes under ultraviolet light conditions.
results_summary: The composite achieved 98.1% Cr(VI) removal under optimal conditions (pH 3, catalyst concentration 2 mg L-1, Cr(VI) concentration 200 mg L-1, hole scavenger 0.4% w/v, 30 min UV exposure). The process followed pseudo-second-order kinetics and Langmuir/Temkin isotherms, indicating high photocatalytic efficiency.
population_specificity: Laboratory study (no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Catalyst concentration 2 mg L-1, hole scavenger 0.4% w/v.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of SmVO4/UiO-66-NH2 nanocomposites in degrading tetracycline hydrochloride (TCH) under simulated solar light irradiation.
results_summary: The study found that SmVO4/UiO-66-NH2 nanocomposites enhanced light absorption and charge transfer, degrading TCH by 50% in 90 minutes under solar light, compared to 30% degradation by bare SmVO4 nanorods. The composite improved photoelectrochemical properties and photoredox efficiency for TCH degradation.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on antibiotic degradation).
effective_dosage: Not specified (simulated solar light irradiation used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the color stability of unsteamed and steamed beech wood under long-term sunlight exposure in interiors.
results_summary: Unsteamed beech wood darkened to a pale brown color (∆E* = 13.0), while steamed beech wood lightened to a pale brown hue (∆E* = 7.1), showing 52.2% smaller color changes. Steaming improved color stability and partial resistance to photochemical reactions induced by UV-VIS solar radiation.
population_specificity: Beech wood (Fagus sylvatica L.) samples

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of ZnO/g-C3N4 nanocomposites in photocatalytic degradation of textile effluents under sunlight.
results_summary: The study found that the 0.75:1 ZnO/g-C3N4 catalyst degraded up to 80% of textile effluents within 120 minutes and reduced physicochemical parameters without phytotoxic effects on fenugreek plants.
population_specificity: Textile effluents (in vitro and phytotoxicity tested on fenugreek plants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of sunlight-induced photochemical processes and microbial interactions in transforming algal-dissolved organic matter (ADOM) in eutrophic water.
results_summary: The study found that microbial processes were more effective at reducing DOC and short-wavelength CDOM, while sunlight was more effective at transforming longer-wavelength CDOM and fluorescent components. Simultaneous photochemical and microbial processes showed inhibitory effects on DOC decay rates but increased protein-like substances.
population_specificity: Eutrophic water environments (not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Natural solar light exposure (specific intensity/duration not quantified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the multifunctional role of vitamin D, its importance in fortification, and its management, including sunlight exposure as a key source.
results_summary: The study highlights that sunlight exposure is crucial for vitamin D synthesis, which has protective effects against various diseases, including inflammation, cancer, and infections, and supports overall well-being. However, awareness and consistent sunlight exposure for vitamin D synthesis decline post-pandemic.
population_specificity: General population (not specified further)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness of oral photoprotectors in mitigating the harmful effects of sunlight on the skin.
results_summary: The study found that systemic photoprotection, particularly through oral supplements with antioxidant properties, can complement topical photoprotection to reduce UVR-induced skin damage by modulating oxidative stress and inflammation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the health benefits and risks of sunlight exposure, focusing on its association with all-cause mortality, cardiovascular health, and vitamin D synthesis.
results_summary: Sunlight exposure was linked to reduced all-cause, cardiovascular, and cancer mortality in epidemiological studies. Benefits were attributed to both vitamin D-dependent and independent pathways, such as nitric oxide photomobilization, though oral vitamin D supplementation showed limited effects.
population_specificity: Individuals from the United Kingdom and Sweden (epidemiological data).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically analyze the association between vitamin D (serum levels and supplementation) and injury occurrence in dancers, as well as its potential effects on muscle function.
results_summary: The study found promising but limited evidence that higher vitamin D serum levels or supplementation may reduce injury occurrence and enhance muscle function in adolescent and elite professional ballet dancers. The evidence is constrained by a low number of studies, small sample sizes, and methodological limitations.
population_specificity: Adolescent and elite professional ballet dancers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether indoor versus outdoor training significantly influences vitamin D levels, considering sunlight exposure.
results_summary: Outdoor athletes had a mean serum vitamin D level 3.73 ng/mL higher than indoor athletes, though the difference barely failed to achieve statistical significance. The impact of training type on vitamin D levels was influenced by multiple confounders.
population_specificity: Athletes (indoor vs. outdoor training groups)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether maternal 25(OH)D levels, demographics, comorbidities, or sunlight exposure influenced the correlation between maternal and umbilical cord blood 25(OH)D levels.
results_summary: The study found a very strong correlation between maternal and umbilical cord blood 25(OH)D levels, which remained robust regardless of maternal demographics or comorbidities. Sunlight exposure was one of the factors examined, but the abstract does not detail its specific impact on the correlation.
population_specificity: Pregnant women admitted to the labor ward (n=298, with 235 successful paired samples).
effective_dosage: Not specified for sunlight exposure; vitamin D supplementation doses mentioned were 10,000 IU/week and 20,000 IU/week.
study_duration: Not specified for sunlight exposure; blood samples were taken at admission and immediately after delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of sunlight radiation, vitamin D supplementation, and home isolation on seasonal changes in 25(OH)D concentration and biomarkers in young soccer players.
results_summary: The study found significant seasonal changes in 25(OH)D concentration, with sunlight exposure contributing to higher levels in summer (T4). However, 8-week vitamin D supplementation did not have a lasting effect on 25(OH)D levels.
population_specificity: Forty elite young soccer players (age 17.2 ± 1.16 years).
effective_dosage: 5,000 IU of vitamin D for the supplemented group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the photocatalytic activity of Fe3O4-FeVO4 and xRGO/Fe3O4-FeVO4 nanocomposites under sunlight illumination for degrading pollutants like methylene blue, phenol, and brilliant green.
results_summary: The study found that adding RGO enhanced visible light absorption and narrowed the band gap energy, improving photocatalytic activity. The 10%RGO/Fe3O4-FeVO4 nanocomposite showed the highest photodegradation efficiency for methylene blue and phenol under sunlight.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on nanocomposites)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of vitamin D supplementation on nonskeletal health outcomes, including its association with various diseases and conditions.
results_summary: The study found that while vitamin D deficiency is linked to multiple nonskeletal diseases, supplementation does not consistently improve major medical outcomes, even when deficiency is corrected. Screening and supplementation are recommended primarily for high-risk populations.
population_specificity: High-risk patients (e.g., elderly, women with osteoporosis, individuals with low sunlight exposure) and general populations with nonskeletal diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether a wearable UVB LED device could effectively increase serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels in healthy adults.
results_summary: The study found a significant increase in serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels in the experimental group compared to the control group after 2 and 4 weeks of intervention. However, 11.8% of participants in the experimental group dropped out due to mild, self-limiting adverse skin reactions.
population_specificity: 136 healthy adults.
effective_dosage: Two minutes daily (one minute per forearm) of UVB light exposure at 285 nm.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of reduced sunlight exposure during the COVID-19 pandemic on serum vitamin D levels in people under age 18.
results_summary: The study found significantly lower serum 25(OH)D levels during the pandemic, except in infants, suggesting reduced sunlight exposure negatively impacted vitamin D levels in children and adolescents.
population_specificity: People under age 18 years (excluding infants under 1 year).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between sunlight and vitamin D-related exposures and the risk of multiple myeloma.
results_summary: The study found insufficient evidence to support an effect of sunlight or vitamin D-related exposures on multiple myeloma risk. Many studies had high risk of bias or were of lower quality.
population_specificity: People of European ancestry (primarily, based on VDR polymorphism analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the importance of adequate vitamin D supply and compare the specifics of administering various vitamin D analogues versus vitamin D in geriatric patients, particularly those with Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: The study highlights the high prevalence of vitamin D hypovitaminosis in the elderly, especially in central Europe, and associates it with diseases like Alzheimer's. It discusses the pharmacokinetics, binding affinity, and potential side effects of various vitamin D analogues, emphasizing their pleiotropic effects relevant to Alzheimer's and geriatric comorbidities.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals, particularly those over 60 years old and those suffering from Alzheimer's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between serum 25(OH)D levels (a marker of vitamin D, influenced by sunlight exposure) and atopic dermatitis (AD), and the effect of vitamin D supplementation on AD severity.
results_summary: The study found significantly lower 25(OH)D levels in AD patients compared to healthy controls, with severe AD cases showing even lower levels. Vitamin D supplementation improved AD symptoms.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (1882 cases across 20 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between vitamin D deficiency (linked to reduced sunlight exposure) and the risk or severity of COVID-19.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D deficiency, often due to insufficient sunlight exposure, is associated with increased risk of COVID-19 illness or severity, though interventional studies on supplementation have been inconclusive.
population_specificity: People living in temperate zones, those with reduced sunlight exposure, and individuals with darker skin pigmentation.
effective_dosage: Not specified (mentions "regular daily vitamin D supplementation" and "large bolus doses" without exact amounts).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between vitamin D deficiency (potentially mitigated by sunlight exposure), depression, and testosterone levels in middle-aged and elderly men.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D deficiency is associated with depression in older men and that vitamin D may play a protective role in depression through its effect on testosterone. Sunlight exposure or vitamin D supplementation was recommended as a low-risk intervention.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and elderly men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the association between SNPs in vitamin D pathway-related genes and vitamin D status as well as muscle traits in healthy adults, hypothesizing that genetic factors could influence these outcomes.
results_summary: The review identified significant associations between certain SNPs (e.g., in GC and CYP2R1 genes) and vitamin D levels, but only low confirmation rates for SNPs linked to muscle traits. The study provides a comprehensive update on these genetic associations.
population_specificity: Healthy adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of sunlight in vitamin D synthesis and its broader physiological effects.
results_summary: The study found that sunlight exposure leads to vitamin D synthesis, which functions as a multifunctional hormone influencing immune, cardiovascular, endocrine, and metabolic systems, with potential roles in depression, pain, and cancer.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether seasonal variations in immune markers are influenced by sunlight and vitamin D levels.
results_summary: The study found that seasonal variations in immune markers occurred independently of vitamin D status, suggesting sunlight or other environmental factors may play a role. Vitamin D supplementation did not affect nTregs but attenuated seasonal changes in IFN-γ production.
population_specificity: 62 subjects randomized equally to vitamin D or placebo groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare Ultraviolet B radiation levels and their association with circulating 25(OH)D concentrations in women of the same ethnicity living in England and Brazil.
results_summary: The study analyzed data from 135 Brazilian women in England and Brazil but did not explicitly report the findings regarding sunlight's effects on vitamin D levels in the abstract.
population_specificity: Brazilian women living in England and Brazil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of vitamin D supplementation and sunlight exposure on vitamin D concentrations in Brazilian women living in high versus low latitudes.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation increased serum 25(OH)D concentrations in both groups, regardless of UVB exposure, with no significant changes in placebo groups. The study found no significant effect of UVB exposure on postintervention vitamin D levels.
population_specificity: Brazilian women living in England (51°N) and Brazil (16°S), mean age 31.39 ± 8.7 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review vitamin D metabolism and natural sources, including sunlight, to encourage lifestyle changes that prevent deficiency.
results_summary: The study found that sunlight is the primary source of vitamin D, providing 90% of the body's needs, and emphasized controlled sun exposure as a preventive strategy for osteoporosis and other deficiency-related diseases.
population_specificity: General population and individuals with risk factors for vitamin D deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of vitamin D, including sensible sunlight exposure, in reducing COVID-19 infectivity and severity.
results_summary: The study suggests that maintaining adequate vitamin D levels, through supplementation or sunlight exposure, may protect against COVID-19 by enhancing immune function, regulating the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, and improving endothelial health. However, conclusive evidence from randomized clinical trials is still pending.
population_specificity: General population, with implications for COVID-19 prevention and treatment.
effective_dosage: Maintain serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D at least 30 ng/mL (75 nmol/L), preferably 40-60 ng/mL (100-150 nmol/L).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prevalence of Vitamin D deficiency in PEG-fed patients and its relationship with sunlight exposure, serum proteins, and nutritional intervention.
results_summary: The study found low initial Vitamin D levels in PEG-fed patients, which remained low despite nutritional intervention, and a correlation between Vitamin D and serum albumin but not transferrin.
population_specificity: 200 PEG-fed patients (118 males), aged 22-92, with protein-energy malnutrition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether encouraging nursing home residents to spend time outdoors could increase serum 25(OH)D levels and improve mental well-being.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a significant increase in serum 25(OH)D levels and reported better self-perceived mental health after spending time outdoors daily during summer, while the control group showed no significant changes.
population_specificity: Nursing home residents aged >65 years in southern Sweden.
effective_dosage: 20-30 minutes daily between 11 a.m. and 3 p.m.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential role of vitamin D (via sunlight exposure) in preventing or mitigating COVID-19 morbidity and lethality.
results_summary: The study found insufficient evidence to establish a cause-effect relationship between vitamin D deficiency and COVID-19 outcomes but suggested further research is needed to assess potential benefits of sunlight exposure or supplementation.
population_specificity: General population, with emphasis on countries with high prevalence of hypovitaminosis D.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether the observed associations between 25-hydroxyvitamin D metabolites and type 2 diabetes (T2D) were causal using Mendelian randomization analysis.
results_summary: The study found observational associations between higher levels of 25(OH)D and lower T2D risk, but Mendelian randomization analysis did not support a causal relationship. The epimeric form C3-epi-25(OH)D3 showed a positive observational association with T2D, but no causal link was confirmed.
population_specificity: Participants of European descent from multiple cohorts, including EPIC-InterAct, EPIC-Norfolk, EPIC-CVD, Ely study, and the SUNLIGHT consortium.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether red and near-infrared light in sunlight, rather than vitamin D, could explain the observed health benefits of sunlight exposure.
results_summary: The study suggests that red and near-infrared light (photobiomodulation) may underlie the health benefits of sunlight, with preliminary evidence from RCTs indicating potential clinical benefits for chronic diseases.
population_specificity: General population, with focus on chronic age-related diseases (e.g., cancer, diabetes, cardiovascular disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of sunlight exposure in maintaining vitamin D levels, particularly in HIV-infected individuals, and its potential benefits for musculoskeletal and cardiovascular health.
results_summary: The study suggests that sunlight exposure is effective in preventing vitamin D deficiency, which is crucial for HIV-infected individuals, and highlights its role in immune function and disease progression. However, factors like ethnicity, skin pigmentation, and antiretroviral therapy may influence outcomes.
population_specificity: HIV-infected individuals
interactions: Antiretroviral therapy may contribute to vitamin D deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if low vitamin D status affects hepatitis B vaccine response and whether vitamin D supplementation (including simulated sunlight) post-vaccination influences this response.
results_summary: Low vitamin D status was associated with poorer hepatitis B vaccine response, but vitamin D supplementation (including simulated sunlight) starting 3 days after vaccination did not improve the response.
population_specificity: Study 1 involved 447 adults; Study 2 involved 119 men.
effective_dosage: Simulated sunlight (1.3× standard-erythema dose, 3×/week for 4 weeks, then 1×/week for 8 weeks).
study_duration: 12 weeks total (4 weeks at higher frequency, 8 weeks at lower frequency).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether current sunlight exposure guidelines are effective for increasing vitamin D levels in individuals with vitamin D deficiency.
results_summary: Sunlight exposure (20-30% body surface area for 30-60 minutes/day, 3 times/week) was insufficient to overcome vitamin D deficiency, while vitamin D supplementation (800 IU/day) showed a larger increase in serum 25(OH)D levels.
population_specificity: Korean adults aged 20-49 years with serum 25(OH)D levels < 20 ng/mL.
effective_dosage: 20-30% body surface area exposure for 30-60 minutes/day, 3 times/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the dual effects of sunlight exposure—its risks (e.g., skin cancer) and benefits (e.g., vitamin D synthesis and anticancer effects).
results_summary: Sunlight exposure can cause skin cancer via UV-induced DNA mutations but also promotes vitamin D synthesis, which may regulate anticancer effects through mechanisms like DNA damage repair, apoptosis, and mTOR pathway modulation. The study suggests balanced sun exposure is beneficial for health.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion on sunlight effects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of cholecalciferol supplementation (a form of vitamin D, often associated with sunlight exposure) on angiogenic parameters in breast cancer patients treated with tamoxifen.
results_summary: Cholecalciferol supplementation significantly reduced Ang-2 and VEGF-A levels in premenopausal women and Ang-2 levels in patients without vascular invasion, while increasing Hif-1 in patients with vascular or lymphatic infiltration.
population_specificity: 52 breast cancer patients treated with tamoxifen, with 22 participants analyzed per group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and compile a comprehensive list of genes associated with altered serum levels of 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25[OH]D) to better understand genetic determinants of vitamin D deficiency.
results_summary: The study identified 35 genes linked to serum 25(OH)D concentrations, 27 of which are not commercially available for clinical screening. Functional analysis confirmed their role in vitamin D pathways and related diseases, highlighting their potential importance in clinical practice for identifying patients with altered vitamin D metabolism.
population_specificity: Not specified (genetic study, likely general population with focus on genetic variants affecting vitamin D levels).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare serum vitamin D levels and patterns of ultraviolet light (sunlight) and dietary exposure among patients with active and inactive noninfectious uveitis and population controls.
results_summary: Participants with active uveitis had significantly lower serum vitamin D levels than inactive uveitis patients and local population estimates. Sun exposure was associated with decreased uveitis activity in vitamin D-deficient participants.
population_specificity: Adult patients with active and inactive noninfectious uveitis recruited from tertiary hospitals and a private ophthalmic practice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the complexities and concerns of advocating sunlight exposure as a public health approach for increasing vitamin D status.
results_summary: The study highlights that while sunlight stimulates vitamin D synthesis, environmental and personal factors can impede this process, making dietary approaches more reliable for addressing deficiency. It also notes that naturally rich dietary sources of vitamin D are limited and intakes are generally below recommendations.
population_specificity: General population in both low- and high-income countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether natural sunlight exposure plus vitamin D supplements could improve delayed early motor development in infants from mothers with perinatal depression.
results_summary: Sunlight plus conventional vitamin D supplements (400IU/d) improved infant motor development more effectively than vitamin D alone, with 7-14 hours/week of sunlight exposure yielding the best motor scores and lowest cortisol levels.
population_specificity: Infants (2-day-old) of mothers with perinatal depression.
effective_dosage: Sunlight exposure (7-14 hours/week) plus vitamin D (400IU/d).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sun exposure or oral vitamin D supplementation could significantly increase serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25OHD) concentrations and compare their effects on cardio-metabolic markers.
results_summary: Both sun exposure and oral vitamin D supplementation significantly increased serum 25OHD concentrations, with similar efficacy between the two interventions. The study also suggested potential differences in their effects on cardio-metabolic markers.
population_specificity: Vitamin D-deficient adults in Seoul, Korea (37°N latitude).
effective_dosage: Sun exposure (daily ≥20-30 min around noon); oral vitamin D (500 IU/d).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize evidence on the association between serum 25(OH)D (influenced by sunlight exposure) and cognitive function, considering influential factors like study design and obesity.
results_summary: Most observational and longitudinal studies showed a significant link between low serum 25(OH)D and compromised cognition, but randomized controlled trials on vitamin D supplementation yielded inconsistent results. Methodological variations and confounding factors (e.g., sunlight exposure) complicated conclusions.
population_specificity: Predominantly White participants, despite higher serum 25(OH)D deficiency in minority populations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between vitamin D deficiency (including sunlight exposure) and Parkinson's disease risk, and whether sunlight or vitamin D supplements improve Parkinson's symptoms.
results_summary: Sunlight exposure (≥15 min/week) was significantly associated with a reduced risk of Parkinson's disease, but vitamin D supplements did not significantly improve motor function in patients.
population_specificity: Patients with or at risk of Parkinson's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether solid-organ transplant recipients (SOTRs) in a Mediterranean region were vitamin D-deficient due to reduced sunlight exposure.
results_summary: The study found that SOTRs had low calcidiol levels (mean 18 ± 9 ng/mL), indicating a high risk of hypovitaminosis D, particularly in autumn/winter, despite living in a sunny region. Avoiding sun exposure to prevent skin cancer was noted, but vitamin D supplementation was recommended if deficiency was detected.
population_specificity: 78 solid-organ transplant recipients (30 lung, 29 kidney, 19 liver) not receiving vitamin D supplements.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review strategies to prevent and control vitamin D deficiency (VDD) in children, focusing on supplementation and food fortification rather than sunlight exposure.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the high prevalence of VDD in India, particularly among children and adolescents, and discusses supplementation and food fortification as strategies to combat VDD, but does not specifically evaluate sunlight's effects.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents in India, with a focus on those with vegetarian diets, high melanin skin content, and limited access to fortified foods.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the immunomodulatory effects of vitamin D derived from sunlight and its potential role in preventing and treating type 1 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D, produced through sunlight exposure, exhibits immunomodulatory effects that may reduce the risk of type 1 diabetes and alleviate symptoms by downregulating adaptive immunity and reducing inflammation. Clinical studies suggest vitamin D supplementation can be beneficial as adjuvant therapy.
population_specificity: Individuals with or at risk of type 1 diabetes mellitus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sunlight exposure has beneficial effects on blood pressure and cardiovascular disease, independent of vitamin D.
results_summary: Solar exposure was inversely associated with blood pressure in most cross-sectional studies and with cardiovascular disease/mortality in cohort studies. Clinical trials showed mixed results, with some reporting short-term BP reduction.
population_specificity: Human studies (observational and interventional, no specific subpopulation mentioned).
study_duration: Varied (e.g., 6 weeks in one trial, short-term UVA exposure <30 min in others).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prevalence of vitamin D deficiency in renal transplant recipients and assess the relationship between serum 25(OH)D levels and other biochemical parameters, including the role of sunlight exposure.
results_summary: The study found a high prevalence of vitamin D insufficiency in renal transplant recipients, with no significant impact of sunlight avoidance on serum 25(OH)D levels. Vitamin D supplementation and sensible sun exposure were suggested as potential strategies to improve vitamin D status.
population_specificity: Adult renal transplant recipients (80 participants, 68 males, mean age 38.11 ± 11.47 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of sunlight exposure alone versus sunlight exposure combined with vitamin D2 supplementation on 25(OH)D levels in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Sunlight exposure alone led to a slight decrease in 25(OH)D levels, while combining sunlight with weekly vitamin D2 supplementation (20,000 IU) significantly increased 25(OH)D levels. However, this benefit was not observed in women aged over 60.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal Thai women aged 50-70 years.
effective_dosage: Weekly 20,000 IU vitamin D2 (in the combination group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the physiological understanding of vitamin D, its endogenous synthesis through sunlight exposure, and the potential cardiovascular risks and benefits associated with supplementation versus sunlight-derived vitamin D.
results_summary: The study found that while observational studies linked low vitamin D levels to increased cardiovascular risk, randomized controlled trials did not confirm cardiovascular benefits from supplementation. It highlighted concerns about excess vitamin D causing vascular calcification in animal models and noted differences in biodistribution between sunlight-derived and supplement-derived vitamin D.
population_specificity: General population (with emphasis on those diagnosed with vitamin D deficiency)
